w:r.w:t: A Cat, a Parrot, and a Bag of Seed:

There is a man that is in need of transporting three items, across the river to the other side, safely and not lose any of the items in the process. The problem here seems to be that these three items, the cat, the parrot, and the seed, have a tendency to eat each other if left alone and unattended. With only enough room left in the boat for item at a time, it could make it very difficult for him to cross the river without losing an item. The issue with getting these items across the
is that the cat will eat the parrot and the parrot will eat the seed if left alone. Figuring out
to take first, second, and last can be pretty difficult. If you take the parrot first then you still have the issue with the cat or the seed on the other

Now if you somehow can make it work, have the parrot perch on either the man’s shoulder or the side of the boat while he transports the cat and then the seed. This way the parrot is technically out of the way and there is still enough room for one more inside the boat. With the parrot perched with the man at all times then he won’t have to worry about an item being eaten while he isn’t looking.

It seems that you have twenty loose socks in a drawer and ten of them are black, six of them are brown, and four of them are white. You then have to choose two loose socks in the dark and hope that they match. The problem is that when it’s dark you can’t see the color of the socks that you are grabbing until you pull them closer to your face. There are a couple different things that you could do in this situation. You could not care that your socks don’t match, you could turn on a light or grab your cell phone, or you

could match up your socks before putting them in the drawer. If you do not care that your socks don’t match then just grab two socks and then go about your day as usual. If you turn on the light then you’d be able to see what you are grabbing, or if you can’t turn on a light then grab your cell phone and use the backlight. The last solution is to just do what I do, match the socks up before you put them in the drawer. That way all you have to do is grab one bundle and your good to go with no worries.

There is a little girl that is counting using her left hand; her thumb is one, her pointer finger is two, her middle finger is three, her ring finger is four, and her pinkie is five. If the girl is counting to ten, the finger that she would stop on is her pointer finger. If she is counting to 100 the finger that she would stop on is her ring finger. Now if she’s counting to

, the finger that is likely to stop on is her middle finger. There really aren’t any constraints in this problem except maybe the fact that she is only using her left hand and that she will always land on a different finger. I myself tried counting, from 1 to 10 and 1 to 100, on my left hand the way it is described, but unless I can actually see this little girl in action then it is just a guess as to which finger she will land on while counting.
